sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Parents frequently report retaining unused opioid pills following their child’s surgery due to fear of untreated postoperative pain. Assessment of pain in adolescents with neurocognitive disability is challenging. We hypothesized that parents of adolescents with neurocognitive disability may report less opioid use and higher opioid pill retention.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Adolescents (13–20y) undergoing elective surgery (posterior spinal fusion, hip reconstruction, arthroscopy, tonsillectomy) were prospectively enrolled from a tertiary children’s hospital from 2019–2020. Only adolescents prescribed opioids at discharge were included. Parents completed a preoperative survey collecting sociodemographic characteristics and two postoperative surveys at 30- and 90-days. Neurocognitive disability was determined at time of enrollment by caregiver report, and included adolescents with cerebral palsy, severe autism spectrum disorder, and discrete syndromes with severe neurocognitive disability.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Of 125 parent-adolescent dyads enrolled, 14 had neurocognitive disability. The median number of opioid pills prescribed at discharge did not differ by neurocognitive disability (29, IQR:20.0–33.3 vs 30, IQR:25.0–40.0, p=0.180). Parents of both groups reported similar cumulative days of opioid use (7.0, IQR:3.0–21.0 vs 6.0, IQR:3.0–10.0, p=0.515) and similar number of opioid pills used (4, IQR:2.0–4.5 vs 12, IQR:3.5–22.5, p=0.083). Parents of both groups reported similar numbers of unused opioid pills (17, IQR:12.5–22.5 vs 19, IQR:8.0–29.0, p=0.905) and rates of retention of unused opioids (15.4% vs 23.8%, p=0.730).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The number of opioid pills prescribed did not differ by neurocognitive disability and parents reported similar opioid use and retention of unused opioid pills. Larger studies are needed to identify opportunities to improve postoperative pain control for children with neurocognitive disability.
